Graphical abstract A series of transition metal-modified hydrotalcite precursors (HT-M, M=Cr3+, Mn2+, Fe3+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+ and Zn2+) were prepared by using the “memory effect” of Mg-Al hydrotalcite. Then, the mixed oxides with different composition were obtained by thermal decomposition of as-prepared hydrotalcite precursors at 773K, and their physicochemical properies were characterized by thermogravimetry and differential thermogravimetry (TG-DTG), X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 adsorption–desorption, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), scanning electron micrograph (SEM) and CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) technique. It was found that the mesoporous structure was formed during calcination. More important, the basicity of the calcined hytrotalcites (HTC-M) samples was depended on the type of transition metal. Simultaneously, they were used as solid base catalysts and evaluated for the synthesis of diethyl carbonate (DEC) from ethyl carbamate and ethanol. Among them, HTC-Mn exhibited maximum activity with the DEC yield of 56.7% under optimum reaction conditions. Then, the correlation between their basic properties and catalytic performance was studied in detail for the HTC-M catalysts. Furthermore, HTC-Mn catalyst could be readily recycled while maintaining high catalytic activity toward this reaction. Keywords Diethyl carbonate Ethyl carbamate Ethanol Hydrotalcite Transition metal Mixed oxide 1 Introduction As an environmentally benign building block, diethyl carbonate (DEC) is becoming increasingly important in the chemical industry. It is mainly used as a cabonylation and an ethylation reagent to produce a series of important chemicals via reaction with alcohol, phenol, amine, hydrazine, ester and other compounds [1–3]. DEC can also be used as a raw material in the fields of producing polycarbonates, green solvent, and the electronic chemical for lithium battery [4]. Moreover, due to its high oxygen content and favorable gasoline-water distribution coefficient, DEC is considered as an ideal additive for gasoline in comparison with dimethyl carbonate and ethanol [5]. Furthermore, as a replacement for methyl tert-butyl ether (MTBE), DEC could decompose to CO2 and ethanol when released into the environment, showing good eco-friendly property [4–6]. Thus, the effective synthesis of DEC becomes more and more important. The commonly used method to produce DEC is the reaction of ethanol with phosgene [7]. Great efforts have been done to develop non-phosgene routes, including oxidative carbonylation of ethanol, transesterification of organic carbonate, and decarbonylation of diethyl oxalate [8–11]. Unfortunately, each of the aforementioned processes has some commercial, technical or environmental shortcomings such as toxicity of phosgene, corrosion and low conversion. The most attracting DEC synthesis method is from the reaction of ethanol and CO2, which is the major greenhouse gas and also a cheap, nontoxic, abundant C1 feedstock. It is an interesting reaction that converted CO2 into an added value product. However, the DEC yield is very low because of serious thermodynamic limitations, which may limit the practical applications [12,13]. An alternative synthesis route is the ethanolysis of urea, which represents an activated form of CO2. The reaction of CO2 and ammonia producing urea is the most important process involving the chemical utilization of CO2 and about 108 tons of urea are produced per year worldwide. The industrial process utilizes the Bosch–Meiser urea process, developed in 1920s [14]. Thus, the reaction of urea and ethanol utilizes two cheap, readily available and non-toxic reactants in a simple process. Additionly, the by-product NH3 can be recycled and further reacted with CO2 to product urea without waste emission, making this reaction quite atom economical. It is famous that the reaction of urea and ethanol can be divided into two steps: the intermediate ethyl carbamate (EC) is generated first and further converted to DEC by reaction with ethanol. The first step of the reaction is fast and highly selective even without catalysts. However, the second step of the reaction, EC to DEC, is more difficult than the first step [15,16]. Consequently, dividing this reaction into two isolated steps would be a more promising approach toward the synthesis of DEC. Therefore, the key to the two-step technique is to effectively promote the second reaction, which is the rate-control step for the reaction of urea ethanolysis, with proper catalyst. Several kinds of catalyst including organometallic compounds, metal salts and metal oxides have been tested toward the direction reaction of urea and ethanol or its analogs [17–19]. Among them, ZnO possessed high catalytic performance for the reaction of urea and ethanol. However, for the reaction of EC and methanol, it didn’t exhibit satisfactory property. In fact, ZnO was a precursor of homogeneous catalyst for the DEC synthesis from urea and ethanol [16]. Xin et al. have reported that La2O3 could be used as a basic catalyst for urea ethanolysis, but it exhibited low specific surface, which was a disadvantage in heterogeneous catalysis, led to unsatisfied catalytic performance [20]. As to the isolated second reaction, metal oxide bases were tested in a batch reactor, but the DEC yield was very low [16]. An et al. have discovered that ZnO–PbO mixed oxide showed good activity for the DEC synthesis. However, it was prone to generating homogeneous coordinates Zn(NCO)2(NH3)2 and dissolved into the reaction medium [21]. Very recently, Wang et al. reported the synthesis of DEC using slag-based catalysts. Though high catalytic performance was achieved, it was noticeable that these catalysts were not easily obtained because the slag raw materials were only provided by the iron and steel company in China [22]. Therefore, it is still a challenging task to explore high active and stability heterogeneous catalytic materials that are obtained via a simple and repeatable way for the synthesis of DEC from EC and ethanol. The Mg-Al mixed oxides that originate from thermal decomposition of hydrotalcite (HT) exhibit the advantages of homogeneous microstructure, high specific area and stability against sintering, along with tunable basicity [23–25]. Thus, they have been used as solid base catalysts, catalyst precursors and catalyst supports in many reactions. More important, the layered HTs can be restructured by exposing the calcined material to water. After modified by various cations, these mixed oxide materials presented a higher catalytic activity than that of Mg-Al mixed oxides toward many reactions [26–30]. It has been demonstrated that transition metals such as Ni and Fe containing hydrotalcite-derived mixed oxides were effective solid base catalysts for transesterification reactions [31–33]. However, to the best of our knowledge, there are few reports on the catalytic performance of transition metal-modified Mg-Al mixed oxides toward the DEC synthesis from EC and ethanol. In this work, the transition metal-modified mesoporous Mg-Al mixed oxides were prepared from the precursors of Mg-Al hydrotalcites containing transition metal, and then were used as catalysts for the DEC synthesis from EC and ethanol. The effect of the insertion of transition metal on the textural, chemical structures and basicity of the Mg-Al mixed oxides as well as their catalytic performances were investigated in detail. In addition, the reaction parameters were evaluated to optimize the reaction conditions and the DEC yield could reach 56.7% under optimum reaction conditions. Finally, based on the results of catalyst characterization and reusability test, a stable heterogeneous catalyst with high activity was successfully developed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation The Mg-Al hydrotalcite precursor was prepared by co-precipitation method as described elsewhere [29], and the atomic ratio of Mg2+:Al3+ was 3:1. Typically, two aqueous solutions, a metal salt solution of Mg(NO3)2·6H2O and Al(NO3)3·9H2O (100mL) and a mixed solution of NaOH and Na2CO3 precipitant (100mL), were prepared and then were added dropwise with stirring to 100mL deionized water. This addition was performed over 1.0–1.5h and the pH value was maintained close to 10 by addition of suitable amounts of a 2M NaOH solution. The resulting slurry was aged at 353K for 12h under stirring in the mother liquid. The as-prepared product was obtained after being filtered and washed with deionized water until pH=7. The filter cake was dried at 373K in air for 12h. In this work, the resulting Mg-Al hydrotalcite was referred as HT-0. Finally, the HT-0 sample was calcined in oven at 773K for 7h under a flowing stream of pure N2 to obtain the Mg-Al mixed oxide, which was denoted as HTC-0. Transition metal-modified Mg-Al hydrotalcite (HT-M, M=Cr3+, Mn2+, Fe3+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+ and Zn2+) precursors were prepared using the “memory effect” of hydrotalcite according to the literature [27,34]. Typically, 1.0g the as-prepared HTC-0 was treated with an aqueous M n+ (n =2 or 3) nitrate solution (0.1mol/L, 100mL) with stirring at room temperature for 48h to reconstruct into the layered hydrotalcite structure. The resulting products were filtered, washed several times with deionized water and dried at 373K for 12h. Consequently, the HT-M precursors were obtained. Then the transition metal-modified Mg-Al mixed oxides were prepared in oven at 773K for 7h under a flowing stream of pure N2. Here, theses samples were denoted as HTC-M, where M stood for the type of transition metals. 2.2 Characterization Thermal decomposition of the catalyst precursors was studied by the thermogravimetric (TG) method using a NETZSCH STA-409 thermal analyzer. The samples were heated from 303 to 1023K at 10K/min under nitrogen. Power X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were measured on a Rigaku Miniflex diffractometer using a Cu target with a Ni filter in a 2θ range of 5–80°. Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms were obtained at liquid nitrogen temperature, 77K on a Micromeritics ASAP-2020 instrument (Norcross, GA), using static adsorption procedures. The samples were degassed at 573K prior to the measurement. The BET isotherm and BJH were used to obtain specific surface area and pore volume, respectively. The morphology of the samples was obtained using a Hitachi S4800 scanning electron micrograph (SEM) operated at 20.00kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed over a Thermo Scientific k-Alpha spectrometer with Al anode (Al kα =1486.6eV) operating at 72W and spot size of 400μm under ultrahigh vacuum (10−7 Pa). Survey scans were measured at constant pass energy of 200eV and region scans at 50eV. The background pressure was 2×10−9 mbar and during measurement 3×10−7 mbar Argon because of the charge compensation dual beam source. The binding energies were calibrated internally for surface charging by adventitious carbon deposit C (1s) with E b =284.5eV. Data analysis was performed using CasaXPS software. The basicity of the catalysts was measured by CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD). Catalysts (0.1g, 40–60 mesh) were placed in the quartz reactor bed. After 5h pretreatment in Ar flow at 773K, the catalysts were cooled to room temperature. Then, they were saturated with pure CO2 (30L/min) using a six-way valve for 3h and then flushed with Ar (40L/min) flow to remove all physical adsorbed molecules. Afterward, the CO2-TPD experiments were started from 303K to 973K with a heating rate of 10K/min under Ar flow (40L/min), and the desorbed CO2 was detected by an AMETEK mass spectrometer. CO2 peak area was quantitatively calibrated by injecting CO2 pulses. 2.3 Catalytic test Reaction of EC and ethanol was carried out in a 100mL stainless steel autoclave with a magnetic stirrer and a reflux column. In a typical experiment, 0.1mol EC, 1mol ethanol and 0.8g catalyst were put into the reactor. Then, it was rapidly heated to 463K and kept for 8h with magnetic stirring. The stirring speed was 600±20rpm, and the temperature error was less than 1K. After the completion of reaction, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature. The product mixtures in the autoclave were weighed, centrifuged and then determined by a GC-950 gas chromatography configured with a PEG-20M capillary column and a flame ionization detector (FID). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural and structural properties of the prepared materials Fig. 1 illustrates the weight losses and weight loss rates of the hydrotalcite precursors during calcination, which presents that all the HT-0 and HT-M samples were successfully transformed into corresponding mixed oxides. In general, the thermal decomposition (weight loss) of the samples consisted of two steps. The first step at 335–481K included two overlapped peaks, which could be assigned to the removal of physically absorbed and interlayer water [29]. It was notable that the introduction of transition metal reduced the temperature of interlayer water loss for all the HT-M samples. This might be because that these M n+ cations might decrease the strength of hydrogen bonds between water molecules and interlayer anions [23]. The second weight loss peak at 631–676K could be due to the elimination of both the hydroxyl groups from the hydrotalcite-like (HTl) network and the carbonate anions from the interlayer anion, resulting in the collapse of the layered structure [29]. As shown in Fig. 1, this peak position also shifted toward lower temperature with the insertion of transition metal cations, which indicated the decrease of the thermal stability of HT-M samples. According to previous report, the introduction of these M n+ cations could decrease the electrostatic interaction between the layers and anions, which then would lead to lower thermal stability and facilitate mass loss [23]. These results also revealed the successful incorporation of transition metal cations into the hydrotalcite lattice. The XRD patterns of HT-0 and HT-M precursors are presented in Fig. 2(a). It can be seen that all the samples showed the typical peaks for HTl structure at about 2θ of 11°, 23°, 35° 38° and 46°, which were assigned to (003), (006), (009), (015) and (018) crystal planes in the layered structure, respectively. At the same time, the in-plane X-ray diffraction from plane (110) and (113) could also be found at about 60° and 61° for all the compounds [35,36]. No other crystalline phases were detected. So, after the calcination-reconstruction process, the well-defined HTl structure was largely retained for these HT-M samples. It was well-known that the HTl characteristic could be depicted by two cell parameters: a (2d 110) and c (3d 003), which were calculated on the basis of XRD analysis, assuming a hexagonal crystal system for the compounds and the results are listed in Table 1 . It was observed that parameter a, which was at range of 3.05–3.07Å for the average cation–cation distance, followed Vegard's law for solid solutions, and corresponded to the expected value on the basis of Mg: Al ratio of 3. In addition, the parameter c (23.03–23.88Å) was in agreement with the interaction of carbonate anions [29]. These results indicated that most the transition metal cations could be incorporated into the hydrotalcite layers by adopting the “memory effect” of HT. At the same time, the XRD patterns also presented that the trivalent cation-modified HT-Cr and HT-Fe compounds exhibited less peak intensity and order compared to the other divalent cation-modified HT-M compounds, which was consistent with the results in the previous report [37]. Besides, Table 1 also gives the surface meal compositions of the HT-0 precursor and the reconstructed HT-M compounds. It could be found a surface enrichment of Al for HT-Cr and HT-Fe materials, but a surface enrichment of Mg for divalent-metal-modified samples. At the same time, the surface compositions of the precursors, as determined by XPS are compared with the chemical compositions of the precursors measured by ICP in Table 1. It was clearly seen that the surface was considerably depleted of Mg and transition metals, while the same surface was enriched in Al. This was in accordance with the results in previous report, where Cu:Al atomic ratios in surface were decreased significantly when Cu–Zn–Al–Zr hydrotalcite-like compounds were synthesized [38]. Fig. 2(b) shows the XRD patterns of the samples after calcination. Clearly, heat treatment at 773K destroyed the HTl structure, since no characteristic reflections of HTl compounds were detected in the XRD patterns. This phenomenon suggested that HT and HT-M materials were completely decomposed at this temperature. Consequently, HTC-0 and HTC-M mixed oxide catalysts were successfully obtained in the present work. Obviously, these mixed oxide catalysts exhibited, in all cases, the same peaks at 2θ =37°, 43°, and 62°, which were corresponded to the periclase MgO-like structure (PDF No. 45-946). No diffraction peaks due to Al2O3 or M2On appeared. Meanwhile, the lattice parameters calculated from the position of the 2θ =43° of this-like MgO structure (see Table 2 ) were all less than that of pure MgO (4.21Å) [39]. Thus, it was confirmed that Al and M cations were dissolved in the MgO lattice to form a solid solution, which might enhance the catalyst stability during catalytic reaction. The textural properties of mixed oxide catalysts were valued by N2 adsorption–desorption measurement. The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and corresponding pore size distribution of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 . All these samples displayed type-IV isotherms with clear hysteresis loops at higher relative pressure. Simultaneously, their pore sizes were widely distributed around 5–40nm. So, the mesoporous structures were formed during calcination for these catalytic materials. These hysteresis loops were narrow, indicating that the mesoporous pores were regular. At the same time, the hysteresis loops had features of H3 type (IUPAC classification), which was usually associated with solids consisting of platy shaped particles. This was in accordance with traditional view of these types of mixed oxides [26]. More important, because a large amount of CO2 was released from HT precursors during calcination, these mixed oxide samples presented higher surface area and pore volume than that of corresponding HT-M precursors [40]. This might be favorable for them to exhibit high catalytic ability. In addition, XPS data in Tables 1 and 2 show that HTC-M catalysts exhibited higher surface M concentration but lower surface Mg2+ concentration compared to the HT-M precursors, revealing that the doped transition metals existed mostly at the surface of the mixed oxides. SEM images of the HT-0 and HT-M precursors are shown in Fig. 4 . Evidently, it can be seen that the morphology of HT precursors have changed after the calcination-reconstruction process. The hexagonal plate-shaped crystals of the HT-0 precursor were transformed to flower-like plates with many smaller flakes at the surface for all divalent cation-modified HT-M precursors. This phenomenon indicated that the reconstruction with divalent cations mainly took place through a surface dissolution–reprecipitation mechanism. In contrast, more disordered morphologies were seen for the reconstruction with trivalent cations. This might be due to an intense dissolution–reprecipitation process in the bulk phase [37,41]. In addition, nitrogen adsorption measurement results presented that HT-M samples had higher surface areas and pore volumes that that of HT-0, suggesting the more open structures were formed for these HT-M samples (see Table 1). 3.2 XPS investigations Fig. S1 presents the O 1s XP spectra for HTC-0 and HTC-M mixed oxides. For comparison, HT-0 precursor was also analyzed by XPS. Clearly, two XPS peaks were found for all the samples. The higher biding energy (BE) peak at about 531.4eV was assigned to the surface metal-hydroxide species. The lower BE peak at 529.3eV was characteristic for surface O2− species [42]. The increase of O2− character was detected for mixed oxides, which was consistent with the presence of strong Lewis basic sites in these HTC-0 and HTC-M catalysts after calcination at 773K. 3.3 The surface basicity of mixed oxides catalysts The surface basicity of mixed oxides catalysts was measured by CO2-TPD and the basic species could be assigned according to the temperature at which peaks appeared. At the same time, the total basicity (basic sites amount per unit weight of catalysts) and surface basic site distribution can be evaluated by this characterization. Higher desorption temperature and higher basicity pointed to higher base strength. In the present work, the CO2-TPD profiles are shown in Fig. 5 . Obviously, all the profiles can be split into three peaks, which can be assigned to the weak (∼375K), moderate (∼540K) and strong basic sites (∼700K), respectively [43]. On the other hand, the basicity of all samples is listed in Table 2. One can see that the moderate temperature peak was more intense (49.3–59.3% of total number of basic sits) for these samples. According to previous reports, these moderate basic sites were mainly ascribed to metal-oxygen pairs (such as Mg-O, Al-O and M-O). The low temperature peak can be attributed to adsorption at surface Brönsted basic site (OH− groups), and the high temperature peak can be associated with the strong Lewis basic sites of low-coordinated oxygen atoms (O2− ions) [37,40,43]. Obviously, the basic strength distribution of the HTC-M catalysts varied as a function of the modified transition metal as shown in Table 2. The total number of basic sites decreased when it was modified by Cr and Fe compared to the transition-metal-free HTC-0 catalyst. However, the catalysts exhibited more basicity when it was modified by Mn, Co, Ni, Cu and Zn than that of HTC-0. In the present case, the low temperature peak was simulated by Gaussian (see Fig. 5). As a result, the amount of moderate and strong basic sites could be obtained by the difference between the total number of basic sites and the amount of weak basic site. Considering the amounts of both moderate and strong basic sites, their basic densities decreased in the following sequence: HTC-Mn (191.0μmol/g)>HTC-Cu (167.2μmol/g)>HTC-Co (154.4μmol/g)>HTC-Ni (149.2μmol/g)>HTC-Zn (139.5μmol/g)>HTC-Fe (129.2μmol/g)>HTC-0 (126.2/g)>HTC-Cr (123.0μmol/g). Thus, insertion of transition metal into Mg-Al mixed oxide can enhance the number of both moderate and strong basic sites except Cr3+. Thus, on the basis of the above-mentioned characterization results and discussion, it was demonstrated that the transition metal could be used to fine-tune the structural, textural and chemical properties of the Mg-Al mixed oxide calcined from hydrotalcite. More important, the HTC-M mixed oxide catalyst obtained from “calcination–reconstruction–calcination” process presented more open structure, higher surface area, pore volume, and surface transition metal concentration than that of the hydrotalcite precursors. In addition, the modification of the transition metals also had an influence on the surface basic property, which potentially affected their catalytic performance for the DEC synthesis. 3.4 Catalytic performance 3.4.1 The reaction system of EC and ethanol to synthesize DEC The reaction system of EC and ethanol could be described approximately by expressions 1–3 no matter what catalysts were used [20–22]. (1) NH2COOCH2CH3+CH3CH2OH→CH3CH2OCOOCH2CH3+NH3 (2) NH2COOCH2CH3+CH3CH2OCOOCH2CH3 →CH3CH2NHCOOCH2CH3+CH3CH2OH+CO2 (3) CH3CH2OCOOCH2CH3 →CH3CH2OCH2CH3 +CO2. At first, the amino of EC was substituted by ethoxy group in ethanol to generate DEC. The product DEC, which was a favorable ethylating agent for amino group, could further react with EC to yield N-ethyl ethyl carbamate (NEEC). As a result, the by-product NEEC might increase correspondingly with the increase of the DEC concentration. Furthermore, at a relatively high temperature, DEC could decompose into diethyl ether and carbon dioxide in the present of solid basic, acidic oxides [44,45]. It should be mentioned that the by-product diethyl ether could not be detected by gas chromatography because it was easy to volatilize when the autoclave was opened. Herein, the catalysts were evaluated by EC conversion, DEC and NEEC yield in the present work. 3.4.2 Effect of transition metal modification The catalytic performance of various catalysts is summarized in Table 3 (Entries 1–9). Notably, the reaction of EC and ethanol hardly occurred in the absence of catalyst (Enty 1). However, HTC-0 exhibited high activity toward the DEC synthesis, yielding 29.4% DEC (Enty 2). Under the same reaction conditions, the DEC yield differed significantly among the HTC-M catalysts. HTC-Cr gave the lowest DEC yield of 27.3% (Enty 3), whereas HTC-Mn showed the highest DEC yield of 56.7% (Enty 4). Thus, HTC-M catalyst possessed higher activity for the DEC synthesis compared to HTC-0 sample, and their catalytic performances were depended on the type of transition metals. It should be mentioned that for these mixed oxides catalysts, their catalytic activity decreased in the order HTC-Mn>HTC-Cu>HTC-Co>HTC-Ni>HTC-Zn>HTC-Fe>HTC-0>HTC-Cr. 3.4.3 Effect of basic property Generally speaking, in a substitution reaction, strong nucleophilic group was prone to replacing a weak one. Because NH2 − was a stronger nucleophile than CH3CH2O−, converting EC with ethanol into DEC was hardly achieved without catalyst. Apparently, this was a base-catalytic reaction. According to previous report, the function of solid base catalysts was to activate CH3CH2OH through the abstraction of H δ+, and consequently the CH3CH2O δ−, which would react with EC to produce DEC, was generated [15,46]. As a result, it was supposed to that the higher base strength lead to the more negative charge of CH3CH2O δ− and consequently the lower was the free energy of CH3CH2O δ− with EC. Then, a higher EC conversion was acquired. In this work, HTC-Co and HTC-Cu presented 247.8 and 241.6μmol/g total basicity, respectively (see Table 2). However, the EC conversion achieved over HTC-Cu (67.5%) was more than that acquired over HTC-Co (61.5%). This was the same for HTC-Ni and HTC-Zn. As mentioned above, the introduction of transition metal remarkably enhanced the moderate and strong basic sites; therefore, their catalytic ability might be closely related to the amounts of moderate and strong basic sites. Indeed, according to the discussion above, the sequence of EC conversion achieved over these mixed oxides catalysts consisted with that of their amounts of both moderate and strong basicity. In other words, the weak basic site could not activate ethanol in the present case. The ability of catalyst for activating ethanol only originated from their moderate and strong basic sites. In order to further clarify the correlation between the EC conversion and the amounts of both moderate and strong basic sites, we illustrated the catalytic activity at 2h when the reaction was at the beginning in Fig. 6 . It could be found that the EC conversion was in good agreement with the trend of basicity of both of moderate and strong basic sites. This further revealed that it was the moderate and strong basic sites that acted as active sites for this reaction. Thus, the insertion of transition metal into Mg-Al mixed oxides significantly increased the moderate and strong basic sites, and then sharply enhanced the EC conversion to produce DEC. 3.4.4 Influence of reaction conditions The reaction conditions were further optimized over HTC-Mn catalyst. Fig. 7(a) illustrates the effect of reaction temperature. The conversion of EC consistently enhanced with the increase of temperature, but the DEC yield reached top at 463K and then decreased. In theory, the high temperature was appropriate for synthesis of DEC, since this reaction was an endothermic reaction [47]. However, higher temperature also shortened the time needed to reach maximum DEC concentration and accelerated the rate of side reactions. Accordingly, the yield of by-product NEEC increased significantly when reaction temperature increased at the cost of DEC consumption. At the same time, the thermal decomposition of DEC might aggravate gradually. Therefore, the suitable reaction temperature was 463K in the present case. Fig. 7(b) presents the effect of reaction time. The DEC yield increased with increasing the reaction time and reached a maximum value of 56.7% after 8h, and then, the consumption of DEC in the further reaction surpassed gradually the formation of DEC from EC. Thus, 8h was optimum for obtaining high DEC yield. As shown in Fig. 7(c), the conversion of EC always monotonically rose with the increase of catalyst amount, but the DEC yield reached the maximum of 56.7% at 0.8g and then decreased. This could be attributed to the promotion of the side-reaction of DEC with EC to form NEEC. Thus, the suitable catalyst amount was 0.8g in the present work. 3.5 Reusability and stability of HTC-Mn catalyst The most active HTC-Mn catalyst was investigated for its reusability and stability, and results are presented in Fig. 7(d). After the first run, used HTC-Mn sample was separated by filtrating, and washed with ethanol several times, dried in oven at 353K and reused without any pre-treatment. To our delight, HTC-Mn could be recycled and reused at least four times without significant loss of activity. Additionally, the recovered catalyst after reused four times was analyzed using SEM and XRD techniques. SEM revealed that the sheet-like morphology was unchanged after the catalyst was used four times (see Fig. 4). Simultaneously, XRD results confirmed retention of the original MgO-like structure (Fig. 2(b)). It could be seen that diffraction peak number was as the same as the fresh one, and the peak intensity did not show any significant change. Therefore, the HTC-Mn catalyst possessed higher stability than previously reported zinc-based catalysts for this reaction and a heterogeneous catalyst with high catalytic performance and stability was successfully developed. 3.6 Comparison of HTC-Mn catalyst activity with other reference catalysts Catalytic activity of HTC-Mn catalyst is compared with other reported catalysts and the comparative results are listed in Table 3 (Entries 10–19). Among the different catalysts, ZnO presented high activity toward the reaction of urea and ethanol, but hardly catalyzed the reaction of EC and ethanol [4,47]. Acidic oxide Al2O3 did not show any catalytic ability [22]. Compared to Al2O3, PbO, ZnO–PbO and basic oxides including MgO, CaO and La2O3 exhibited relatively high activity. However, the DEC yield was lower than 40% [21,22,48]. The solid base catalysts derived from waste slag could improve DEC synthesis the DEC yield could reach 43.6%. Unfortunately, the raw material for preparing such basic catalysts was only provided by iron and steel company in China [22]. The present HTC-Mn catalyst showed higher activity compared to the other reported catalysts. Meanwhile, the DEC selectivity was 80.8% in this work, which was higher than that in other reported work. In addition, the present catalyst was reusable, and its preparation method was simple and repeatable. Based on above results, we can conclude that the HTC-Mn is an active, stable and practical catalyst for the DEC synthesis from EC and ethanol. 4 Conclusions Various transition metal-modified mesoporous Mg-Al mixed oxides were prepared via a facile “calcination-reconstruction-calcination” procedure from Mg-Al hydrotalcites. With introduction of transition metals, the obtained HTC-M presented much higher base-catalytic performance than the corresponding pure HTC-0 for the DEC synthesis from EC and ethanol, due to their improved moderate and strong basic sites. A good correlation between the EC conversion and the amounts of the moderate and strong basic sites has been established. More important, the catalytic performance of HTC-M catalysts was depended on the type of transition metal and HTC-Mn possessed maximum activity for this reaction. Under optimum reaction conditions, the EC conversion and DEC yield can reach 70.2% and 56.7%, respectively. Furthermore, HTC-Mn catalyst could be reusable for several times without any pre-treatment and exhibited consistent activity. Simultaneously, this catalyst exhibited high stability on the basis of SEM and XRD characterization. coredata.dc:description: A series of transition metal-modified hydrotalcite precursors (HT-M, M=Cr3+, Mn2+, Fe3+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+ and Zn2+) were prepared by using the “memory effect” of Mg-Al hydrotalcite. Then, the mixed oxides with different composition were obtained by thermal decomposition of as-prepared hydrotalcite precursors at 773K, and their physicochemical properies were characterized by thermogravimetry and differential thermogravimetry (TG-DTG), X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 adsorption–desorption, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), scanning electron micrograph (SEM) and CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) technique. It was found that the mesoporous structure was formed during calcination. More important, the basicity of the calcined hytrotalcites (HTC-M) samples was depended on the type of transition metal. Simultaneously, they were used as solid base catalysts and evaluated for the synthesis of diethyl carbonate (DEC) from ethyl carbamate and ethanol. Among them, HTC-Mn exhibited maximum activity with the DEC yield of 56.7% under optimum reaction conditions. Then, the correlation between their basic properties and catalytic performance was studied in detail for the HTC-M catalysts. Furthermore, HTC-Mn catalyst could be readily recycled while maintaining high catalytic activity toward this reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Transition metal-modified mesoporous Mg-Al mixed oxides: Stable base catalysts for the synthesis of diethyl carbonate from ethyl carbamate and ethanol
